thread.title: Meeting to discuss downtown Savannah interstate flyover plans set for Thursday | savannahnow.com
thread.title_full: Meeting to discuss downtown Savannah interstate flyover plans set for Thursday | savannahnow.com

author: Dash Coleman
title: Meeting to discuss downtown Savannah interstate flyover plans set for Thursday | savannahnow.com
text:
Photos Back | Next An option for modified interstate access to downtown Savannah is shown. (courtesy Symbioscity) Back | Next An option for removal of interstate ramps onto Montgomery Street in downtown Savannah is shown. SIGN UP FOR SUBSCRIBER BENEFITS As a Savannah Morning News / savannahnow.com subscriber, you're eligible for members-only discounts. Download your coupons now. By Dash Coleman Want to chime in on how local officials should handle the removal of the Interstate 16 flyover in downtown Savannah? Thursday’s your chance.
The Metropolitan Planning Commission will hold a Reclaiming Old West Broad Street meeting from 5-7 p.m. Thursday at the Savannah Civic Center. Planners want to showcase proposals for tearing down the Interstate 16 ramp leading into downtown, and they want public input on the project.
The general idea of the project is to revitalize Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard, thinking that the ramp divides the corridor, leaving small businesses without much of a customer base. Beyond removing the ramp, which funnels traffic onto a small one-way section of Montgomery Street, the project aims to restore the grid pattern of roads typical of the rest of downtown.
“Essentially, we have two concepts, and each concept has two alternatives,” said Tom Thomson, executive director of the MPC.
Implementation is far off, but what planners need to do now is get approval on a plan and begin the process of a deeper environmental-impact analysis.
One proposal involves re-working the ramps that sit over West Gwinnett Street, which, once the Montgomery Street ramp is destroyed, will be one of the main points of entry into downtown Savannah from I-16.
Other plans include adding a ramp on West Oglethorpe Avenue that would allow traffic
to flow south from downtown to connect with I-16 rather than just north to South Carolina on the Talmadge Bridge.
“My guess is before there’s a development-ready block, we’re probably talking seven to 10 years,” Thomson said.
Plans are to return Montgomery Street to a two-way street after the ramp’s removal.
“Really, what this means is downtown development will move west,” Thomson said.
Planners are still trying to fine tune some funding sources.
Estimated costs run from $67.3 million to $70.3 million depending on which option is selected.
Included at Thursday’s open meeting will be presentations of travel-time comparisons and 3-D models. There will be time for discussion with the project team.
IF YOU GO
What: Reclaiming Old West Broad Street informational meeting and discussion.
When: 5-7 p.m. Thursday; presentation at 5:30 p.m.
Where: Savannah Civic Center, 301 W. Oglethorpe Ave.
Info: www.reclaimingoldwestbroad.org.
